strTooltip: Reduces target's condition until it is damaged or destroyed.
Reduces target's condition until it is damaged or destroyed.
Destroys container to access its contents.
Runs debug and troubleshooting procedures to remove errors in target's software.

strDesc: [us] spends some time admiring the finer details of [them].
strTooltip: Seek a mood boost by witnessing some beauty. Target must be installed.

strDesc: [us] admires [them] and appreciates its aesthetc qualities.
[them] looks at [us] but doesn't feel like admiring aesthetics at the moment. Maybe later.
[us] is too fatigued to do that.

strTooltip: Carefully disassembles an item to maximize salvage. Warning: Dismantling is usually irreversible.
Carefully disassembles an item to maximize salvage. Warning: Dismantling is usually irreversible.

[us] is going to dispense liquid from [them].

strDesc: [us] cannot dispense liquid. It is empty.

strTooltip:
Exercises until too tired, too hot, or purposefully stops.
Two hours of exercise per day are needed to counteract atrophy without meds.

strDesc: [us] is too uncomfortable to do that. [them] goes on standby.
[us] is too uncomfortable to do that. [them] goes on standby.

Transports item to an appropriate storage zone (if one is assigned).

Opens the door. Warning: atmospheric conditions may vary significantly on the other side!
Opens the door. Warning: atmospheric conditions may vary significantly on the other side!

[us] decides to set [them] to a blue color.

strDesc: [us] has been factory reset to PIN 0000.
[us] is doing a hacking crime to [them].

strTooltip: Plays a challenging arcade game, achieving some alone time, autonomy, and escapism from real life fear and meaninglessness.

strDesc: [us] is not interested in playing [them] right now.
[us] is not interested in playing [them] right now because they would rather talk to someone.
[us] is not interested in playing [them] right now because they would rather accomplish something more tangible.

strTooltip:
Plays a game with a companion.
Achieves contact and possibly belonging for you both.
Achieves autonomy and escapism from the fear and meaninglessness of real life.

strDesc: [us] starts a new game of [them] and is deciding character details.
[us] is pursuing an optional side objective in [them].
[us] has reached an intense climactic milestone in [them].
[us] has victoriously overcome an intense climactic milestone in [them], and levels up.
GAME OVER. Maybe next time. [us] stops playing [them].
GAME OVER. [us] was so close to victory. Maybe next time. [us] stops playing [them].
[us] sets [them] to play a random track.
strTooltip: Plays one of the songs available on this device.
Plays Track 1: Dustball Sunrise on this device.
Plays Track 2: Trinity on this device.
Plays Track 3: The Metal Barge on this device.
Plays no music, remaining on standby while still powered.
Plays imaginatively with [them].

strDesc: [us] plays out a little scene with [them].
[us] surveys this land with [them], remarking on it's fertility.
While surveying this fertile land, [them] is suddenly and inevitably betrayed!

strTooltip: Forces open the target using a prying tool.
Repairs a non-functioning, damaged item so it works again.
Hastily breaks down an item to remove it. Produces a few scrap parts.
Applies a patch to rapidly seal gas leaks.
Studies to slowly develop toward gaining a skill. Gains privacy and a sense of achievement, but may get tiresome or lonesome.

strDesc: [us] is not interested in studying with [them] right now.
[us] is not interested in studying with [them] right now because they would rather talk to someone.
[us] is not interested in studying with [them] right now because they would rather find purpose and beauty in life.
[us] prepares to study with [them] by reflecting on what they have already learned and how that connects with their experiences.
[us] is momentarily pursuing a side question only partly related to [them].
[us] has reached a challenging aspect that requires hands-on, interactive practice.
[us] has connected insights motivating deeper exploration of [them].
[us] feels a little burned out on studying for now. Maybe in a few hours.
[us] almost figured it out, but isn't sure it was worth the effort.

strTooltip: Toggles power on/off.
Secures a docked vessel with towing equipment, protecting it from maneuver damage.

strDesc: [us] operates [them] to secure the docked vessel.
strTooltip: Secures a docked vessel with towing equipment, protecting it from maneuver damage.

strDesc: [us] readies [them] to release the secured docked vessel.

strDesc: [us] operates [them] to release the docked vessel.
strTooltip: Releases a docked vessel from being secured with towing equipment. Clamps will now be subject to maneuver damage.
Toggles power on/off.

Takes some time to watch the news.

Takes some time to watch dramatic reruns.

Removes wear and tear on a functioning, but worn-out item.

Uninstalls a part of the ship, so it can be moved elsewhere.

strDesc: You are framed for a crime you didn't commit, and sentenced to prison.
You injure yourself during day-to-day activity.
Your action or inaction causes the accidental death of another.

The plan is a good one and you're happy to be on board. You play lookout for a few weeks and make money in the process.

You clocked the ringleader as a straight shooter so you're shocked when AyoSec comes knocking at your dorm door one night. According to them, you've been orchestrating a theft and smuggling ring.

It's your word against theirs in the brief trial, and they've already dimed out the rest of the crew. You're sentenced to time in the Azikiwe Brig. Time to harden up.

You are approached by a coworker who has developed a less-than-legal method for making cash on the side. Apparently they have been tagging high value salvage as junk in the system for the last six weeks. After the false tag they leave the part onboard the derelict and sell the location to the highest bidder.

This scheme always involves the complicity of the breaker doing the final sweep, and today that happens to be you. The piece in question is a busted reactor, and you know it will fetch a pretty penny on the black market.

It's a big take, if you can pull it off. But there are risks...

You decline the offer but keep an eye on the involved parties. It's a good scheme. Runs like clockwork. After a couple weeks you know all the names, locations, and timings.

You bring this intel to an AyoSec officer. They are shocked by the level of detail. It's not a career case, but it's close enough.

Now you have a friend on the force plus some valuable information to boot.

It's a good scheme. But it would be better if it were yours.

So you play nice for a couple weeks as a lookout all while spreading some vicious rumors about the ringleader to the rest of the crew: that they're working for AyoSec, that they're skimming off the top, that they are going to flip to management at any moment.

It isn't long before everyone involved wants this person out of the way. You play the rational actor during the meeting when everyone decides to beat the shit out of them on the labor barge during the next shift change.

When that dirty work is done, everyone decides you should run the con from here on out. You humbly accept.

Disturbed by this brazen act of theft, you go straight to the highest level manager you can find. The manager calls in their attached AyoSec detail and together the three of you hash out the various culprits in the scheme.

Before you leave the office the manager hands you something as a gift. It's a limited edition Ayotimiwa hoodie. What a treat.

Something about this whole scheme doesn't sit right with you. In fact, you don't like the way this person is looking at you. Do they think they are better than you? Tougher?

You ask them as much and then don't listen to their answer. A scuffle ensues. One thing leads to another and somebody (not you!) gets brained with a crowbar.

If they wanted to avoid said fate, you think to yourself as you flee the scene, then they shouldn't have implied you were some kind of weakling. You sure showed them who the weakling is.

The plan is a good one, but hell if you're going to be the one left holding the bag. You keep a digital record of the false tags as insurance to guarantee you get your cut.

Sure enough, the ringleader tries to squeeze you when it's time to pay up. You use the evidence to blackmail them for a larger share.

And more importantly, you get out clean.

Ship: You discover a spaceship hulk that could still be made spaceworthy. It'll take some elbow grease, and you'll have to source some replacement parts. Plus, technically, it'd be stealing from the junkyard. Stealing junk, but still stealing. The yard owners won't like it when they find out...

You discover a spaceship hulk that could still be made spaceworthy. It'll take some elbow grease, and you'll have to source some replacement parts.

Plus, technically, it'd be stealing from the junkyard. Stealing junk, buuuuut...still stealing. The yard owners won't like it when they find out.

You know what? You're doing it. Screw this life prying metal warts off heaps of junk for your crumbs of daily bread. From now on, you call the shots. Just as soon as you can get this thing flying again...

Shipbreaking is a nearly impossible grind, but you know with enough discipline you can leave each month with a little extra cash socked away. So you cut back on your drinking, swap a few kiosk meals for Trenchers chow, even take an extra shift here and there.

It's not much, but by the end of the year, you've got something that's beginning to resemble a nest egg.

You found an affordable ship! It's a standard shipping container.

With a nav station bolted on.

And that's pretty much all there is to say about it.

Due to a lack of environmental life support and other crucial systems onboard, Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "very low," indicating that it is legal for sale but poses a significant risk of death to crew.

You happen across an ad for a Ryokka Tu-77a salvage pod. It's little more than a tin can with maneuvering jets and life support, but it'll get you around the K-Leg boneyard well enough. More importantly, it could be a means to avoid long lines at the day labour berth, and avoiding the 'salvage tax' levied by yard transports.

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.

Using a cheap, mortgaged derelict as a frame, you're able to scrape together enough spare parts to retrofit your own salvage pod, a comical replica of its factory-line kin. It takes years of hard work, and agonising choices over what can be spared toward your project and what must be sold to survive. But finally it's finished - as finished as it's ever going to be.

Due to the external hull features on this craft, Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "low," indicating that it is legal for sale but poses some risk of death to crew.

You happen across an ad for a heavily used Ryokka Tu-76a endurance salvage pod. There's not much there but maneuvering jets and life support, but it can fly. The endurance model of the TU was built for longer range salvage operations, and so it is equipped with a bed and wash facilities. The one for purchase is in very rough shape, however. It would require some serious elbow grease to bring it back to form.

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.

You happen across an ad for a Ryokka Tu-70a compact salvage pod. These models are simple, mostly just life support and thrusters, but they work just fine for local travel in the Boneyard. The particular TU model available has a smaller floor plan, making it more fuel efficient and lightweight than other Ryokka models.

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.

You happen across an ad for a "classic" Testudo Lilliput test pod. It's a relic from 2038, and not a valuable one. It would look more at home in a museum than in flight. Last time it was in operation might have been as a ferry between Earth and Luna. But it has life support, maneuvering jets, and a Nav Station, so it will do the job. It even comes standard with two jump seats in case you want to start a little crew.

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.

You happen across a seller trying to offload a Testudo Dream. It's a small shuttlecraft used to ferry passengers in local space. It's not pretty, but it has life support, thrusters, and even a few jump seats if you have friends you don't like so well. Might be just what you need to escape the daily grind as a ship breaker!

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.

You manage to find a lead on someone selling a Testudo Melody. It's a small ship with life support, power and thrusters, but many of the vital components are exposed to hard vacuum, making it difficult to maintain without a pressure suit. That said, any ship could be a means to avoid day gigs on OKLG.

Ogiso's Register has given this vessel an OSR of "moderate," indicating that it is legal for sale but does not possess ship systems beyond basic travel and life support.
This "ship" is probably more of a coffin. But it's your coffin, damnit. Free and clear. Besides, there's something kinda poetic about picking over the bones of long-dead vessels in a portable grave.

You're now the proud owner of a Tu-77a, and you can now reach some of the outer derelicts beyond the watchful eye of the yard masters.

Now that you're on your own terms, your next move is up to you. Maybe score a valuable part or two for resale, or reuse? Pull down a platinum tier payout on a gig? Or maybe even discover a ship discarded before its time?

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

Well it ain't much, but at least now you can now reach some of the outer derelicts beyond the watchful eye of the yard masters.

Now that you're on your own terms, your next move is up to you. Maybe score a valuable part or two for resale, or reuse? Pull down a platinum tier payout on a gig? Or maybe even discover a ship discarded before its time?

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

Now that you're on your own terms, your next move is up to you. Maybe score a valuable part or two for resale, or reuse? Pull down a platinum tier payout on a gig? Or maybe even discover a ship discarded before its time?

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

You're now the proud owner of a Testudo Dream, and you can now reach some of the outer derelicts beyond the watchful eye of the yard masters.

Now that you're on your own terms, your next move is up to you. Maybe score a valuable part or two for resale, or reuse? Pull down a platinum tier payout on a gig? Or maybe even discover a ship discarded before its time?

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.

You're now the proud owner of a Testudo Melody, and you can now reach some of the outer derelicts beyond the watchful eye of the yard masters.

Now that you're on your own terms, your next move is up to you. Maybe score a valuable part or two for resale, or reuse? Pull down a platinum tier payout on a gig? Or maybe even discover a ship discarded before its time?

Whatever the case, it beats sweating in a suit all day for someone else's profit. Time to get out there and find your future.
You decide the time isn't right. Yet.

You're drinking at the local watering hole after your shift, when you see the unicorn. They're the scion of an Ayotimiwa executive, sneaking out to rub shoulders and bump uglies with the common folk. You wince as they try to pay for their round in yuan - it's dollars for the likes of us, friend.

If you're careful, and lucky, they could be an opportunity.

Okay, so maybe you've been drinking tonight. Maybe your feelings aren't so much fleece the rich as eat the rich. K-Leg bars are volatile at the best of times, and it takes only a bit of theatricality from you to set the dogs on them and their fancy silk clothes.

It turns ugly, however, when one of their hangers-on reveals herself to be the security detail, and trigger-happy to boot. The subsonic rounds are deafening in the confines of the bar. Suddenly everything is in chaos, people are bleeding on the floor, and AyoSec is on their way. Time you were on yours.

Ah, well. Blacklisted from another bar. It's not such a bad outcome, is it? It's important to keep these things in perspective.

They're a mark if ever there was one. They might as well have a target embroidered on the back of their bamboo silk tunic.

You wait until after the fourth round. When they stagger back from the head, you make your move, brush into them on their way out. They don't notice a thing.

Fuck it. Sometimes the path to riches is a straight line.

Pity you don't notice the security detail until it's too late, which happens to be when she's drawing on you. You grab the gun, you struggle - there's a shot -

And a dead body on your conscience. But you had to have known this was a possibility, right? Eggs, omelettes.

You catch their eye across the crowded bar. A held gaze, a quirk of the brow - that's all it takes. You're that good. It's a crying shame you scrap spaceships for a living.

Sure, it's a quintessential hustle, and to their credit they're savvy enough to realise it, but it's not like it's slave labour. That's an Inner System thing. Six months, then a year: time flies by in comparative luxury.

In the end, they're forced to break it off for an arranged marriage to another Ayotimiwa family. But you'll always have Paris - the only cafe on the asteroid.

There's one commodity that's more valuable than all else, even in a monotown like K-Leg: information. And you'd bet they're full of it.

Sure enough, after ingratiating yourself and making sure their waterskin is continually topped up, the secrets pour out of him. Shocking stuff. Dark. You didn't know Ayotimiwa's CFO's nephew was into that kind of thing. You didn't even know it *could* be a sex thing.

When the shift changes, you're singing in the maintenance access tube together, swearing eternal friendship. But when you sober up, you realise you don't know how to contact them.

The password is 'rosebud'. You choke on the drink you're nursing. Well, at least it wasn't 'password'.

You remotely clone the contents and upload it to the station's dark web for sale, even as you sit there strapped to your stool. Perhaps fifteen minutes later, the scion takes a phone call which leaves them looking as nervous as it's possible to look while thoroughly sauced. Their retinue organises a speedy retreat.

You grin into the nozzle of your waterskin. It shouldn't be this easy.

The password offers you no resistance, but as soon as you're in, you find that your movements feel slow. Everything is taking just a little too long. Every door leads to another door. Nothing is where it should be.

Risking a glance away from your work, you scan the bar, expecting to catch some whitehat grinning back at you. But nobody looks even remotely interested. Where are the hired goons? AyoSec wouldn't let a chump like this go without...

Your PDA is starting to radiate heat. Shit. Shitshitshitshit.

Patrons look on as you claw your way into the PDA's battery compartment, and pull the cell. You knock drinks over, and speedwalk towards the exit, your ears burning with embarrassment.

In the doorway, you pause for one more look. The fact that the scion isn't looking your way tells you all you need to know.

Time to go home and check your bank account. Or what's left of it.

Midway through scrapping yet another hulk, the cockpit of your allotted salvage pod lights up with red tell-tales. Suddenly you're under thrust, as one of the engines sends you spiraling away from the hulk's orbit into the black. It's unresponsive, and nobody has the fuel to come save you; you're expendable.

If you want to live, it's up to you.

These old engines are full of software vulnerabilities, you've known this ever since an exploratory dive, but never had you considered trying to exploit them under 3Gs of thrust.

Suddenly a connection request appears on your Portal. "Tech support here," drawls the cowboy hacker under whom you've been studying. "What seems to be the problem?"

Together you smash the stack on the engine and trigger a reboot. Crisis averted, you start the burn back to the hulk. The unauthorised leave and fuel expenses are docked from your pay, of course.

It takes some truly inventive flying. With judicious timed burns of the RCS you slowly nudge your orbit nearer to that of an oncoming ore hauler. In the last stage of the interception you bail out of the doomed pod, firing every bit of reactant left in suit's maneuvering thrusters, desperately hoping not to become a proverbial bug on the windshield.

They hook you on their way past, and slowly reel in the tether. It's magnetised to your boot. The whole experience is moderately humiliating, but at least you hit it off with one of the friendlier spacers on the ore hauler who insists it's the funniest thing they've seen all year.

This isn't your field of expertise, but the principles of motion are more or less the same anywhere you go. The problem is that one engine is misfiring wildly and counteracting your attempts to correct it. Therefore the solution is to nullify that engine.

Lasering through the engine mount on the hardpoint strangely never came up in the owner's manual, but you suspect if it had, it would be under 'Don'ts'. With good reason: as you break through, the engine shears off, taking a part of the pod's frame with it.

You limp back into port, but the Harbourmaster is none too happy to hear there's another cloud of debris for his crews to track. They fine you for their trouble.

Oh, this. It's a known issue on the Minsheng Alpha series. You've just got to reroute power through the axial breakers to trigger an interrupt request from the thrust control module, at the same time as you hit the manufacturer's security keys and - yep. Simple. Lucky this happened to you - someone else might've been in serious trouble.

Your manager is impressed you escaped without damaging the rig. In a rare display of generosity they offer you a bonus on your weekly pay.

You've seen this accident enough times to know the surest method of survival. Abandon ship!

You quickly strap into the emergency EVA suit and hit the eject early enough that the suit can get you to the nearest salvage crew mate. They pull you in just in time.

Your crew chief is a climber with their eyes on management, so after the accident they make a big show of your resourcefulness and talk about how important human assets are to the Ayotimiwa family. There are cameras and Ayo brass at one of these dog-and-pony shows, and your crew chief presents you with a package sheathed in corporate wrapping paper. Inside you find the EVA suit you wore during the escape, the one that saved your life.

It's a grim reminder of the precarity of the shipbreaking life, but it's also worth more than you make in a month, so you'll take it.

As the pod careens deeper into the black you glance over at the emergency locker, the one where Ayotimiwa stores the vacuum rated EVA suit. It's a terrifying calculation, but at the end of the day you know more about EVA ops than you do piloting, so it looks like your best option. Abandon ship!

You don the suit as quickly as you're able but lose some precious seconds resealing the helmet. In the meantime the sputtering engine has overloaded the intake regulator, which has caught fire. In a matter of moments the entire pod is engulfed and you're still monkeying with the pressure seal on your neck.

You manage to reseal the helmet, open the airlock, and eject the pod before the entire cabin becomes a blazing inferno. Using carefully timed RCS microbursts you coast to a nearby salvage pod piloted by a crewmate who pulls you into safety. It's only after the adrenaline fades you that you notice the burns on your face and neck.

These injuries garner no sympathy from Ayotimiwa, however. They fine you for mishandling, burning, and subsequently abandoning their salvage pod. In a rare act of grace, they allow you to keep your shipbreaking job.

When all's said and done, shipbreaking and scavenging and hustling is a grind. What was once dangerous eventually becomes monotonous. This just so happens to be a phase of your life from which, looking back, you can't remember any interesting events at all. The only thing noteworthy about this particular period of back-breaking 100-hour weeks is what you started doing to cope.

How do you deal with the boredom?

The nice thing about living in space is that all systems are networked. The nice thing about networked systems is that they're made to be broken. Quite literally, judging by some seditious commentary you found hidden in the man pages, once upon a netdive.

Slowly you extend your awareness into the station around you. Security cameras in the alley behind your dormitory? They work for you now. The cleaner robot has been monitoring who disposes of their trash thoughtfully, a satellite element in Ayotimiwa's social ranking system, so you touch up your record. The AI in charge of ambient music programming schedules your favourite songs more often. Sometimes when you lurk these networks you get the strange sense that you're being followed. Other times, you're certain of it.

This is ... a fun distraction, but limiting, and maybe a little sad. This isn't a challenge, it's a waste of your talent. Occasionally you look into a career change. All the network security job postings require academic transcripts, five years experience, glowing recommendations - a valid ID, of course - and the less reputable postings are ... *very* less reputable. Suicide by two bullets to the back of the head less reputable. Forgetting your suit before a spacewalk less reputable.

Back to the grind.

strTitle: Get a Second Job as an Electrician
strDesc:
Propelled by an intoxicating blend of pride and masochism, you find yourself taking a second gig with Ayotimiwa in entry level maintenance. Your job, officially, is to "ensure the working condition of Ayotimiwa consumer-facing assets," but your new coworkers are quick to inform you that what you've actually become is the "kiosk bitch."

The humble kiosk: OKLG is littered with them. The royal red Van Buren Pharma. The lime and gray Gig Nexus.The burnt orange of the Ayotimiwa refuel station.

It's not lost on you that in the early days of the colonization rush these might have been manned jobs, each providing a salary healthy enough to keep at least one spacer housed and fed. But why pay a spacer for what a screen can accomplish twice as fast? Plus, you don't have to give a kiosk their death pay bonus after the screen is inevitably smashed to bits by drunk revelers in the OE.

At first the job doesn't offer much in the way of excitement. Faulty buy button on a Pharma box at NoCo Marina (quick solder job.) Refuel kiosk in the port has a stuck slider (admin reset). Gig Nexus at Azikiwe Estates has a screen flicker (hard smack does it).

But soon enough you discover a strange aptitude for electrical maintenance. Circuit boards begin to present to you as cities in miniature: the copper traces running like tiny roadways, LED diodes flashing like traffic lights beneath capacitors looming like the apartment subscrapers on Tharsis Landing.

The gig doesn't last but your fascination does. Now everytime you pass a kiosk you can't help but press your face against the vents just to get a quick look at the little world inside.

Your Portal pings you as you pass through an Ayotimiwa Communal Recreation Area. 'Old Movie Night!' it reads, 'Shift change plus fifteen.' You cast a dubious glance over the elongated cupboard that is the recreation area, and wrinkle your nose at the lingering tang of burned coffee. Who watches 'movies' anymore? Judging by the room, not more than three adults and a stray HuntCat.

When shift change rolls around, you're staring at the underside of the bunk above you. You're exhausted. But ... Old Movie Night, say your thoughts skeptically. Old Movie Night. Old Movie Night. What moron would - oh dear, we seem to be getting out of bed.

Your guess was close. The only other guest is the convenor and host, someone in Ayotimiwa management moonlighting in what appears to be a hobby. They wave you over from within the smoker's bell. "Welcome." Their voice is muted by the bell, but warm. "You're in time for a classic. Cop Killer, Jason Cheung's action debut. Old Hong Kong, '32." They turns their attention to the wallscreen. The HuntCat fires a spur into the shadows, and bounds over to wring the neck of its prize.

You sleepily observe this and many other 'classics' over the weeks. In addition to Hong Kong action cinema, you see some 40s blockbuster revival, French New Wave, mumblecore, Xinhuan Synthetism, on and on.

Often the films lull you into a deep sleep and further into dreams. There, you find yourself acting as the lead, a desperate bookie with a low hat and a loaded shotgun, or else a lovelorn cab driver cruising the twisted streets of London in search of a fare that will never arrive.

It all comes to a close when you're rostered on to another shift. You and the host remain friends, though, and meet often at the Mescaform to discuss the cinema of yore. Sometimes, on the walk home, you'll recite your favorite lines to a reflection of yourself in the puddles that dot the grubby corridors of the OE.

The Bingham-12 Vacuum Mobility Suit has fifteen major seals - lubricate them. The helmet has its own secondary battery system - check the indicator, but also check the physical battery, just in case, because one time you saw that false report. Re-laminate the torso, groin, and skull with radiation absorbent using a fine brush tip. POLDARN - that's the mnemonic for a user review of the suit's internal metrics, according to Ayotimiwa ... but once you get through it, review the balance calibration, because the mnemonic doesn't cover that for some reason. Check boot soles for micro abrasions and organic detritus. Try to scrounge some more cooling gel,  the heatsink on the 12 series guzzles it down. Check internal fans for dust, because dusty fans are to blood clots what heart attacks are to your sudden asphyxiation ...

At the start of this period, you could do a full check about 8 times per free shift. Toward the end, you're up to 14. It's the kind of thing someone might've called you insane for, if it wasn't so incredibly common.

In one of your more lucid moments, it occurs to you that this routine might well save your life, but it might very well destroy it, too.

Watching Freefall Fighting Championship reruns on your Portal doesn't do it for you anymore. You need to hit someone. You need to get hit. Enough of this death by a thousand cuts, daily grind, BULLshit. It's time you did some physical laundry, and you're separating the aches from the pains. If life is going to hurt, then it's going to REALLY hurt.

You meet in Bay E4, a fact that stays strictly between you all. It's not illegal - Ayotimiwa couldn't give any less of a shit - but if enough people found out, look, it just wouldn't be the same, alright? It feels good to hide the bruises. It feels secret to look at your coworkers and know, yeah, I could take him. In a place where a human life has a dollar value, and not a very big one, you've found a new standard by which to measure yours.

It's the copycats which do you in. Buncha idiots start smacking each other around in the mall's third level plaza, in full view of everyone. Then Ayotimiwa has to introduce and enforce a blanket ban, and you're back to the 3FC channel. At least you have a backlog of fresh content ready to go.

"Super heavy lifter approaching sunward high, inbound from Jade Rabbit, commencing secondary retroburn. Note the indigo markings, she's a security contractor. Wonder what she was doing on Luna?"

"Private cargo ship, The Zenith, taxiing to burn. Isn't that Captain Forrestor's ship? Guess he's taking the Harbourmaster's threat seriously."

"Check out rimward high, hundred klicks - someone's ignored the ATC. There's a couple of stunted pilots playing chicken over who gets right of way. There's a traffic drone on intercept."

K-Leg monitors ships approaching and departing in a several million kilometre volume, so there's always something happening, and there's always someone watching. The Shipping News is a chat server for the latter folk. They're quite happy to explain their jargon to a newcomer, and the complex orbital visualisations soon stop being confusing and become engrossing, even hypnotic. You learn a lot about how many ships come and go from a port, and what kind. In the end this makes you more valuable to Ayotimiwa, and you leverage that for higher pay in the breaker yard.

She's a real beauty, the Testudo Heavy Lifter 448, and it's with a confusing mix of honour and dismay that you're contracted to take her apart.

On day four of the break you're welding through a wall compartment when something catches your eye. You snap off the torch and take a closer look. Your breath catches at the sight: a Miura intake regulator, the apex of the defunct company's technical achievements, today one of the rarest aftermarket parts in the game.

It's popular on other markets, too. Maybe Ayotimiwa don't need to know about this?

Maybe you disapprove of the practice, or perhaps it just isn't worth the risk this time. You've been audited before. It's never fun trying to explain where your extra spending money comes from. Whatever your reason, you notify your supervisor, who in turn notifies their supervisor, and again, and so on. A special team is dispatched from the Ayotimiwa HQ prism, who carefully cut out the offending part, place it in a sealed container, and promptly leave it in the exhaust path of a fusion torch.

You are considered for, but ultimately not awarded, an official letter of commendation. In lieu of said honor you are gifted a t-shirt emblazoned with the Ayotimiwa logo.

In a way, destruction is itself an act of creation. Thousands in fact. A transformation of one thing into many, many things. Into smithereens.

This is on your mind as you take the first crack at the fabled Miura Hydra with a crowbar. Your blow dents the royal blue aluminum housing and knocks something loose in an internal assembly. Two screws and a washer roll out from beneath the machine like the first pieces of candy escaping a doomed pinata.

This is enough to unleash a manic flurry of blows you recall only as a white hot elation. Every muscle in your body dedicates itself to this singular task, a rare harmonious mind-body flow state that produces a rhythm of impacts that sends chunks of ruined metal flying across the entire cabin.

When you finally return to your senses, you can barely recognize the Miura for what it was. A few internal components remain intact. There's blood on your hand. A long channel of it running from a cut on your arm that you can't feel.

You are so exhausted you can barely manage a thought. At last.

It's all too simple. Strip the part out, hide an RFID tag amidst the wreckage, chuck it on the garbage sled. When the sled reaches Overflow Processing (the 'junkyard of junkyards', as the locals would have it), someone sufficiently bribed will find the part, remove it, edit the log, and reroute it back into the hands of one of K-Leg's many fences. You get a finder's fee and a fortnight of prudent paranoia, which soon subsides. Such is life.

Your dream ship - you have one, don't deny it, everyone here does - your dream ship has a Miura regulator. If you're gonna dream, why not dream big? And a pair of Weber ignition lasers, a Zhuangzi reactor, all on a Titan Shipyards frame. Your letters of marque from five different planetary LEOs are framed in the crew mess. Dalisay streams her aerobics routine from your ready room. Wait, where were we? Oh yes: you've disassembled the regulator and you're taking it back to your dormitory, piece by piece, shift by shift. You're going to hide it and sit on it like a small mammal in hibernation. Or maybe a desert flower, waiting for the rain.

This isn't insane. This is perfectly normal behaviour.

Your plan is to move slow and steady, to wait for opportune moments, to stare lovingly at the Hydra only when you are alone with it. But by day seven of the break, the allure of the piece is just too much to handle.

The moment your site manager signals that they are going for a piss break you set to work, convinced you can strip the part out and hide it somewhere safe before they get back.

But while you manage to uninstall the piece, your manager returns to find you stowing it in a lesser known air duct of the 448, and there's nothing you can say to convince them that's where it belongs.

Your manager calls the infraction into AyoSec, and the corp has run your trial and developed sentencing before the end of the shift. Two armed officers lead you offsite and straight to booking.

The AyoSec-run Azikiwe Brig isn't hard time at Prokofiev, but it's not ideal either. You're still going to have to get crafty if you want to get out of here with all your limbs.

strTitle: Bribe Your Boss and Split the Profits
strDesc:
Ayotimiwa's middle management know which way the solar wind blows (rimwards, unless something has gone terribly wrong). Uncle Ayo doesn't want to know about how its legendary black markets are run, and it definitely doesn't want whistleblowers. But, as ever, there's a right way and a wrong way to approach a bribe. And in either case rumors always find a way to get back to the fraud unit of Ayosec.

All this runs through your head as you slip your supervisor a credit chip and ask them to take an early lunch on you. You watch as her eyes glaze over. It's clearly something she's had to do many times before. "Just don't fuck it up," she says brusquely, and heads back to the pod. Good advice in general, you think, as you fire up the welder. Assuming you don't, the part will net you far more than the bribe at the end of the day. A good haul, even though it will inevitably attract a little heat from the authorities.

Despite your best efforts, your dream of owning your own salvage ship still eludes you. You find yourself wondering if a change of strategy is in order.

How will you spend the upcoming year?

Queen of Diamonds on the river. Matches up nicely with your ladies, turns your two pair into a full house. Huang, the guy who got you into this game, is out. The ancient Nigerian shipping magnate folds. The suit, who you guess is an off-duty military contractor by her demeanour, folds. It's just you and the High Roller, and he's been trailing for a while now.

"Tell you what," he says, smiling faintly underneath his mirrorshades. "Let's make this interesting." He tosses a command key for a starship onto the table. The other players go from quiet to deadly still. His only out was the inside straight draw for the straight flush ... and surely he wouldn't bluff with something so valuable. Right?

The high roller flips up suited connectors, exactly what he needed to make the straight flush. One of the best hands in the game and today it's your worst nightmare. He takes back his key fob and every chip you own. The bet leaves you penniless. Back to square one.

The more you think about it, the more you realise the strength of the bluff. This game is off the books, so to speak. Nobody's verified this command key. It could be a novelty belt fob for all you know. That's the double bluff.

You're confident you have his number. You push your chips into the pot and...

He has nothing. Of course. High Roller? Gotta be an act. He's a scammer. The mirrorshades were a dead giveaway - they're not even ironically cool these days.

So goes your thinking as you head to the dock, ready to endure a bit of ribbing at the hand of the harbormaster when you tell them your story.

Except it isn't just a story. The damned thing is really here. It's a deathtrap, mind you. More power than sense. But it's yours now.

"We're playing for cash," you say, looking between the other players in bemusement. "If you don't have the cash, you know what to do."

He shrugs and takes the key back. You win this pot but can't help thinking you've missed a chance to play better.
Folding a full house is never easy. But the game continues, and you still walk away with a decent cash reward at the end of the day.

You consider the small plastic jewel lying on the table, compare it to the tall but diminishing stack of chips that represents your buy-in for tonight's game. On some level, it's a no brainer.

You snatch the key from out the pot, kick off from your chair, and fly toward the door.

The bouncer on the other side isn't prepared for you to bowl past him, sending him careening into a wall garden feature. Cries follow you out the room and down the hall, and you hightail it to the dock.

You'll make some enemies in the underworld for this, and you can kiss your buy-in goodbye. But the ship is yours!

Mirrorshades. Cool idea, only about a hundred years out of fashion, and for good reason. Cyberware is too dumb not to be networked, and once you cracked it, you've been able to see through this poseur's eyes for the last twenty hands. You take a peek and find that for once the guy is actually holding a monster. 

 You try and make a big show about the lay down but something about it doesn't sit right with the off-duty Ayosec officer playing bouncer behind you. You leave before he finishes his counter ops but he follows you outside anyway and then tunes you up for good measure. 

 For whatever reason, he only pockets half of your ill-gotten winnings after the beatdown. Not a bad night, all things considered.

It's hot.

Chronic issues with the neighbourhood's HVAC have metastacised into a full breakdown. Waterboys lug skins of hot exhaust water from portable AC back and forth between the reservoir. Whole dorm families lie comatose in the access hallways, desperate for the airflow from further along the station. While emergency crews attempt to rig up a solution, you and everyone else in Sector 21 are stuck sweating it out.

How do you cope with the heat?

The Linus Torvalds, a Venusian freighter, went missing en route to K-Leg (or so the rumour goes; no-one seems to know the specifics). The Torvalds was apparently carrying some kind of plant drug (again, no specifics) to prevent our grow-ops from coming down with a microgravity-related plant sickness or growth defect.

All anybody knows for sure is that food stocks are running out, and the station is in a panic.

The commissary couldn't serve you. You're starving, and you have been for three shifts straight. Folks are eyeing each other over bean pouches, even Trenchers.

How are you going to eat?

Hulks of blackened metal loom all around as you ride the labor barge out to the boneyard. The barge is so overloaded today, they've got some of you clinging to a cargo web full of locked crates.

Crates with emergency supplies they'll, no doubt, deduct from your pay if you dare have an accident.

But the armed guard's back is turned...

Three swings is all it takes, the entire front half of the crate caving under your assault. The few laborers that notice you stare agape, shocked at the display of strength.

All except one, who risks loosening their grip to clap you on the shoulder and nod in approval.

Inside you find a laser torch in pristine condition. It even has a fully charged battery.

You're confident with your first swing, a huge looping crowbar blow that sends the adjacent spacers ducking for cover. Your second swing, however, leaves you impressed with the crate's hearty construction.

 By the fifth failed hit you're dripping sweat and cursing the bloodline of whoever designed what appears to be the strongest crate lock in human history.

 You keep swinging anyway because nobody likes a quitter. The nearby spacers chuckle or drift off as the AyoSec officer floats towards you and places a sympathetic, if condescending, hand on your shoulder.

Ultimately, you're fined for misconduct. In one final blow to your ego, they let you off the hook for any "damage" done to the crate.

These cases have a firmware update vulnerability you were reading about. Using a data cable to your handset, you try a script you've been working on to hack the PIN.

A flash of green and a puff of air signal your success, eliciting silent fist pumps and wide smiles from the neighboring laborers.

As one of the more skilled hull cutters, you're assigned a laser torch for the day. Firing-up your borrowed laser torch and making room between the webbing, a nearby laborer looks around, and organizes a few others to anchor you as you work. Within seconds, an orange-ringed chunk of the crate, lock and all, floats away to silent cheers from your fellow workers.

You rifle through the crate's contents as quick as you can and burn your arm on molten metal in the process. The score is yours, plus a scar to remember it by.

Some less scrupulous scrap bosses run smuggling on the side, using the labor barge as cover to ferry crates out to buyers. You're willing to bet a mis-labeled crate might put it somewhere you and your buddies could get to unseen, once the barge reaches the site.

 But when you get back to station the site manager fines your team for the missing cargo. To make matters worse, one of your brilliant co-conspirators forgot where they stashed the loot. You make them buy the crew a bottle of vodka and let the fuck up be the running joke of the evening as the three of you cruise the corridors of the OE.

When the shift ends you stop by your manager's office and let them know about the security leak on the labor barge. They appreciate the loyalty and tell you to contact them if you ever need anything.

As you turn to leave the office your manager tosses something to you that you barely manage to catch. It's a limited edition Ayotomiwa shoulder bag. Nice!
Criminals move in, forcing you to leave with only what you can carry.

"Zhou, Zhou, Zhouyi!" a woman calls. You stop what you're doing, mouth dry. So do the dozen or so other day-workers in the cramped dormitory, a 'Silver Class Econopartment' in ASC Barracks.

That's the signal from the next pod over. They're coming.

Outside the door and up the access corridor, you hear the clatter of mag boots marching in double time. A half dozen of your neighbours flee through the back door. Moments later you hear a series of sharp cracks and screams - shocker rounds, you hope.

You've got a moment to act. What do you do?

You saw it coming. To be fair, so did everyone else; crackdowns are almost, but not quite, a regular occurrence in this neighborhood. But unlike everyone else, you did something about it.

The bolthole you prepared, an air vent in the side hull, opens without a hitch. You slither inside just as the first AyoSecs barge into the dorm.

 You watch as they subdue your dorm-mates. Hardly close friends, it nevertheless hurts to watch. Later, as contraband is piled for seizure and serially unlicensed workers are rounded up for transfer to the penal labor sector, you think one of them catches your eye. Yes, you're sure they do - they're looking at you, a bemused smile spreading across their bloody face. For a moment, you think they're about to sell you out.

 But instead, as rough hands pull them away, they wink.

You can't run a grift without preparation. You can't pull one off without a little luck. Fortunately, today you have both.

There's a rumour going around that a bureau of AyoSec inserts plainclothes police into communities like this one. If they exist, they've covered their trail so far. With nothing else to go on, you spent three long nights painstakingly copying, modelling, and printing a fake security badge. It won't pass close inspection, but if it goes according to plan, it won't have to.

As the inspector reaches your position in the lineup, you make sure she catches sight of your badge, flat against your palm. You stare straight ahead. This is a confidence game. First one to blink loses.

The inspector gives you a long look, but when she rifles through your belongings, she doesn't react to what you have hidden in there.

"Your work visa is invalid," she says impassively. "I'll let you off with a warning this time."

She moves on down the line. Two weeks later you see an Ayotimiwa deposit into the account you set up in the forged IDs name.

You're on the straight and narrow. Your work visa is legal and valid. You aren't carrying any contraband, and your rent is paid up two weeks in advance.

As the AyoSec officers customarily rifle through your closet, one of them steps towards you and offers their card.

 "Reach out if you ever see anything you shouldn't," they say.

Always nice to make a friend. Still, you think to yourself as the officers slam the door behind them, it'd be nice to find a berth with a quieter nightlife.

On some stations, hackers are monitored with the same vigilance as states seeking nuclear capabilities back on Old Earth. Do they have the technology needed to perform a cyberattack? Do they have the motivation? The skills, the opportunity, the support network?

This is a good example of why such precautions exist.

It's the work of ten tense seconds to isolate the corridor the AyoSecs are advancing down. It's three keystrokes to trigger a vacuum alarm. You hear the thuds as the bulkheads close, trapping them inside.

By the time the sysop can untangle the mess you leave behind, the raid will be neutered, by social embarrassment if nothing else. Some of your dorm-mates take advantage of the confusion to slip away, hopefully to a less-policed area of the station, if such a thing exists in the Barracks.

A few months back you bought a piece - it's a rough neighbourhood, and the black market likes it that way. It's not even an old world pistol. It's a damned crossbow, printed plastic with a couple of bolts so delicate you suspect they'll snap instead of launch.

Still, it's a hundred foot-pounds of muzzle energy you wouldn't have otherwise.

To your surprise, the bolt doesn't break; instead, it punctures the armor of the first guy through the door. Later, you suspect that's why they were so hard on you with the boot, as you wait in line for the magistrate to hear your case, face still colourful with the bruises.

If crime doesn't pay, and heroism actively costs you, what is left? Anodyne, value-free work, it would seem.

A few months back, you bought a piece for just this occasion: a crossbow. A printed plastic deal. Not the most powerful or flashy weapon on station but you always figured it would do the job.

The first guy through the door is wearing body armor. You hold your fire, certain your bolts won't penetrate.

The next guy in is a ranking captain wearing nothing but dress blues. Must have wanted to look nice for the raid. You put a bolt in his chest and he crumpled to the ground behind a hundred foot-pounds of muzzle energy before drifting out into the hallway behind him.

From there the entire raid goes south: the leaderless goons can't tell which way is up. You and your roommates manage to hold your own in the scrum, and you get out before any more shooting starts.

On your way down the hallway you snatch the officer's credentials, which will fetch a high price on the black market. He obviously won't be needing them anymore.

The Ayotimiwa med-tech takes a glance at your chart, then at your body, then back at your chart. Immunosuppressed, low bone density, hypovolemic—standard condition for a young spacer on K-Leg station, born and raised as you were in the weak microgravity of a 33km asteroid.

Doc says the insomnia is catching up with you. It's chronic around here, something likely caused by radiation and lack of sunlight. Your eyes work well enough for now, but they're still bad and they're getting worse.

Eighteen years old and rapidly approaching middle age. Your muscles are feeble by Mars standards. They wouldn't stand a chance on Earth.

No shit, you say. You're no Earther. And you never will be.

A heart monitor beeps and then beeps again. The bored tech scribbles a few notes and grants your work permissions: healthy enough to strip hulls in The Boneyard, despite everything.

Fine with you. Closer to the ships, after all. And you're going to get one.

The Azikiwe Brig is a sprawling subcompound on the far East wing of OKLG, a warren of dormitories-turned-prison barracks nestled with alarming proximity to the station's main reactor.

In fact, the jail facilities are intertwined with almost all of the station's most dangerous industrial zones: the cacophonous scrap sorting lines, the near-freezing morgue, the foul-smelling waste processing facility and the hot-house hydroponic grow op it fertilizes.

It's here where you do your time: compelled by Ayotimiwa to labor without wage among outcasts both meek and dangerous. You share a dorm with nearly a hundred other souls, all of you stacked like kindling on triple high bunks that leave you ten inches between your nose and the brushed aluminum above it.

But even a hell like this is not without opportunity. You hear things. You meet people. You get in a few scrapes, you find a few friends. By the end of your term you've lived a dozen lives and you have all the scars to prove it.

Plus, free room and board. In a certain light, it might all be worth it…

[us] is seeking secure and prompt delivery of an advanced AI supercomputer with significant power requirements and thermal output. The computer houses [txt1]

Remove the computer from the Pick-Up Locker and install it into a ship with a live power source before the internal battery runs out. After reaching the location of the Drop-off Locker, uninstall the computer and deliver it before it loses remaining power.

WARNING: the device above has power needs that can only be met by an enormous battery bank or a live Inertial Confinement Fusion Reactor. Failure to adequately power the device results in the forfeiture of the gig cost. Client and Gig Nexus accept no responsibility for damage or injury as a result of the device's heat output.

strDesc: [us] attempts to leverage their relationship with [them] to extract valuable intel.
strTooltip:
Attempt to leverage a relationship with target to extract valuable intel.

Target must consider the agent to be a Lover for this to work.

[us] wants to frame [3rd] on [regid_them], but first [us] needs someone to scope it out and see if [them] is there.

 - board [regid_them]
 - Use a PDA to take recon photo of [them]
 - Return to Job Kiosk and Turn-In gig.

[us] is seeking information on the whereabouts of [them], who [txt1]

You are to locate [them] on [regid_them] and use the PDA to take a photograph proving latest location.

[us] wants to show [them] how serious they are after [them] [txt1]


 - board [regid_them]
 - find and hurt [them] badly without rendering them unconscious
 - tell them [us] sends their regards 
 - Return to Job Kiosk and Turn-In gig

[us] is seeking a skilled operator in romantic entrapment who can compromise [them] as part of a plan to [txt1]

Locate [them] on [regid_them] and develop a romantic relationship with them. Once trust is established, extract the relevant information from them and return to the kiosk.

[us] is seeking the services of a private investigator who can investigate the reported death of [them]. The subject was [txt1]

Locate [them]'s body on [regid_them], inspect their body to verify the cause of death, then return that information to the Gig Nexus kiosk.

strTitle: OKLG LEO Begins Arresting Criminal for Stealing a Ship

[us] tells [them] they have the wrong person.

strDesc: [us] thinks back to a time they cheated death, and tries to make themselves feel more accomplished.
strTooltip: Attempts to improve sense of achievement.

Drinks one serving of the liquid or liquid contents.

strDesc: [them] can't inject [us] until the previous injection runs out.

strDesc: [us] decides to activate [them] to produce oxygen.
strTooltip:
Activates chemical reactions that produce slow but steady oxygen, even in vacuum. Once activated, the oxygen candle cannot be deactivated or used later.
For faster pressure, use in a small room.

Activates chemical reactions that produce slow but steady oxygen, even in vacuum. Once activated, the oxygen candle cannot be deactivated or used later.
For faster pressure, use in a small room.

strDesc: [us] decides to refresh the atmo of [them] with bottled gas.
strTooltip:
Partially vents own suit atmo while injecting O2 from a bottle.
Must be airtight and have handheld bottled O2 in inventory.
Warning: Lower pressure in the bottle means less will injects into your suit.

strDesc: [us] has no gas to refresh with.

strDesc: Extra time for UI use. E.g. ending social combat with results visible

strDesc: [them] can't light [us]. Perhaps it's not equipped?

strTooltip: Lights an unlit cigarette in a mouth or hand slot.
Turns a lit cigarette into a cigarette butt.

strDesc: [us] decides to brush their teeth using [them].
strTooltip: Improves hygiene but can only offer benefits every few hours or after eating or smoking.

strDesc: [them] uses [us] to brush their teeth, but since they are decently fresh already, it doesn't help much more.

strTooltip: Improves hygiene by using up water.
